title: Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory
content: The Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (SAIL) has been a center of excellence for Artificial Intelligence research, teaching, theory, and practice since its founding in 1963. See over eight hours of video from Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory researchers speaking on April 13, 2023. Professor Chelsea Finn and PhD Student Tony Zhao have now introduced a system for fine-grained robotic manipulation that relies on low-cost hardware and imitation learning directly from real demonstrations. Are they sentient? Are they safe? Will they take my job? Stanford PhD student Eric Mitchell answers the internet’s questions on AI chatbots From deepfakes to Bing’s chatbot, AI-generated content is everywhere. Here’s how to spot it. The fellows are “early-career scholars represent[ing] the most promising scientific researchers working today. Their achievements and potential place them among the next generation of scientific leaders in the U.S. and Canada.” The Stanford Artificial Intelligence Lab has a rich history which you can learn about in a new video on AI at Stanford from 1962 to 2022. Click “Read More” below to see it. Seeing TidyBot come together in my lab has been fun! And yes, our lab has been exceptionally clean 🧹Many of you commented on the mobile platform which I'm so pleased about seeing it move!Let me tell you the story behind these platforms!🧵https://twitter.com/jimmyyhwu/status/1656982989774127104?s=20 When organizing a home, everyone has unique preferences for where things go. How can household robots learn your preferences from just a few examples?Introducing 𝗧𝗶𝗱𝘆𝗕𝗼𝘁: Personalized Robot Assistance with Large Language ModelsProject page: https://tidybot.cs.princeton.edu  When organizing a home, everyone has unique preferences for where things go. How can household robots learn your preferences from just a few examples?Introducing 𝗧𝗶𝗱𝘆𝗕𝗼𝘁: Personalized Robot Assistance with Large Language ModelsProject page: https://tidybot.cs.princeton.edu  Current benchmarks for testing medical algorithms have a major limitation: They don't indicate how well the tool will perform in clinical workflow. “To truly assess a medical AI algorithm’s value, there needs to be a human in the loop,” says @james_y_zou. https://stanford.io/3nKpSVI The key insight in our work TidyBot: Summarization with LLMs is an effective way to achieve generalization in robotics from just a few example preferences.Check out this great thread by Jimmy Wu who is visiting @StanfordIPRL! When organizing a home, everyone has unique preferences for where things go. How can household robots learn your preferences from just a few examples?Introducing 𝗧𝗶𝗱𝘆𝗕𝗼𝘁: Personalized Robot Assistance with Large Language ModelsProject page: https://tidybot.cs.princeton.edu  Thrilled to be part of #NorCalDBDay, joining a panel on Databases and AI with great minds of @adityagp, @dborkar, @EdoLiberty, @idangazit. Let's dive into the fascinating intersection of #AI and modern #DataWarehouse. See you there! 🚀💡https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/research/event/norcaldb-2023/ Recently Prof. Fei-Fei Li sat down with @AndrewYNg of @DeepLearningAI_ to discuss the past and present state of human-centered #AI, and some of the "audacious questions" yet to be answered. Full interview 👉 https://youtu.be/UNhC6Ox0T0o @drfeifei @coursera @StanfordHAI @StanfordAILab Diyi Yang who focuses on Computational Social Science and Natural Language Processing Sanmi Koyejo who focuses on Trustworthy Machine Learning for Healthcare and Neuroscience   See the Entire Faculty Stanford AI Lab faculty and students enjoy chances to understand and solve the not-yet-doable pain points of industry.
